In the FEEDBACK path (output to inverting input).

Opposite of differentiator!

At the INPUT (between signal and inverting terminal).

Opposite of integrator!

cards.front: Integrator output for square wave input?
cards.back:
Triangle wave

∫(constant) = ramp
Alternating +/- constants → alternating ramps

cards.front: Differentiator output for triangle wave input?
cards.back:
Square wave

d(ramp)/dt = constant
Alternating +/- slopes → alternating constants

H(s) = -1/(sRC)

|H| = 1/(ωRC) → gain DECREASES with frequency
Phase: -90° (output lags)

H(s) = -sRC

|H| = ωRC → gain INCREASES with frequency
Phase: -90° (output leads)

cards.front: What is the DC drift problem in integrators?
cards.back:
DC input → ∫DC dt → ramp → SATURATION!

Even tiny DC offset causes capacitor to charge continuously.

cards.front: How to fix DC drift in integrator?
cards.back:
Add resistor R in PARALLEL with feedback C.

DC gain = R/Rs (finite, not infinite)
Becomes Active Low-Pass Filter.

cards.front: What is the HF noise problem in differentiators?
cards.back:
Gain = ωRC → ∞ at high frequencies!

High-frequency noise gets massively amplified.
Circuit becomes unstable.

cards.front: How to fix HF noise in differentiator?
cards.back:
Add resistor R1 in SERIES with input C.

HF gain → R/R1 (limited, not infinite)
Becomes Active High-Pass Filter.
